University, Beijing 100084, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Dry reforming of methane (DRM) is a novel technology that enables the direct utilization of greenhouse gases (CH4 and CO2) for the production of value-added products. In the DRM reaction, the acid-base characteristics of the catalyst support play a pivotal role in determining the performance of the catalyst. In this study, a series of Co-based catalysts with different alkali earth metal-modified Al2O3 composite supports, specifically m-Al2O3 (m=Ca, Mg, and Ba), were prepared using the impregnation method. Various characterization techniques were employed to investigate the impact of alkaline site modulation on the support surface with respect to anti-sintering and anti-coking properties. The results demonstrate that the m-Al2O3 composite support catalysts, prepared with Mg and Ca modulation, exhibit an abundance of basic sites and oxygen vacancies. This promotes the adsorption and activation of CO2, enhances the rate of carbon elimination, and effectively addresses carbon deposition and metal sintering issues. Notably, the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalyst shows the highest performance under reaction conditions of 750 °C, with CH4 and CO2 conversions reaching 92.3 % and 97.5 %, respectively. On the other hand, the CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 catalysts display poor performance in dry reforming. Kinetic studies indicate that CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalyst significantly reduce the apparent activation energy required for CH4 and CO2 cracking. Furthermore, it is demonstrated that the introduction of alkali earth metals can promote the dissociation of CH4 and CO2. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dry reforming of methane Co-based Alkali earth metal Basic sites Support Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction In recent years, there has been a substantial surge in the emission of carbon dioxide (CO2), resulting in a myriad of issues, including global warming [1-3]. Consequently, the capture and utilization of greenhouse gases, such as methane (CH4) and CO2, have attracted considerable attention. Among various technologies, the dry reforming of methane (Eq. (1)) is regarded as the most promising approach for effectively harnessing both greenhouse gases [4-7]. This process not only converts CH4 and CO2 into valuable synthesis gas (H2 and CO), but also enables their further utilization in the Fischer-Tropsch process, facilitating the production of methanol, along with other valuable liquid fuels and chemicals [8-10]. (1) C H 4 + C O 2 ↔ 2 CO + 2 H 2 , Δ H 298 K Θ = 247 kJ / mol The thermodynamic stability of the methane-carbon dioxide molecule means that the reaction usually takes place at temperatures above 700 °C [11,12]. However, at higher temperatures, certain side reactions can occur. For example, the reverse water-gas shift reaction (Eq. (2)) leads to a decrease in the H2/CO ratio. Additionally, CH4 decomposition (Eq. (3)) and the Boudouard reaction (Eq. (4)) result in carbon deposition and catalyst deactivation [13]. Therefore, the main challenge for industrializing the methane dry reforming is to develop catalysts that are both highly active and stable [14-16]. (2) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O , Δ H 298 K Θ = 41 kJ / mol (3) C H 4 ↔ C + 2 H 2 , Δ H 298 K Θ = 75 kJ / mol (4) 2 CO ↔ C + C O 2 , Δ H 298 K Θ = − 172 kJ / mol Noble metal catalysts, such as Rh and Pt, have been discovered to exhibit high catalytic activity and resistance to metal coking and carbon buildup [17,18]. However, their application is limited by their high cost. In contrast, Ni-based catalysts offer a more affordable alternative while maintaining comparable activity and stability to noble metal catalysts. Nevertheless, Ni-based catalysts are susceptible to carbon deposition and metal sintering at high temperatures, causing their deactivation [19,20]. On the contrary, cobalt (Co)-based catalysts, a distinct category of transition metal catalysts, feature CH4 active sites on the cobalt surface that exhibit greater ease of activation compared to those on the nickel surface [21]. Additionally, cobalt demonstrates a pronounced affinity for oxygen, thereby effectively enhancing the concentration of oxygen species and facilitating carbon gasification on the catalyst surface [22,23]. Consequently, cobalt-based catalysts demonstrate superior resistance to carbon accumulation. In a previous study, it was found that Co-based catalysts modified with La produced abundant basic sites and oxygen vacancies, which were favorable for CO2 adsorption activation as well as cumene gasification [24]. Horlyck et al. [25] discovered that monometallic nickel catalysts loaded with La-doped alumina improved the stability of catalysts by inhibiting the CO disproportionation reaction and the methane cracking reaction. Carrero et al. [26] observed that the incorporation of Zr, Ce, and La into Co/SBA-15 resulted in smaller cobalt crystals, improved metal dispersion, and stronger metal-carrier interactions between the cobalt metal and the carriers. Wang et al. [27] investigated the effect of introducing lanthanum on the catalytic performance of Co/WC-AC catalysts used for DRM and discovered that the addition of La not only inhibited the oxidation of the WC species to WO3 but also provided better resistance to carbon deposition during the reaction process. Furthermore, La had a significant effect on the type of carbon deposits. Boudjeloud et al. [28] prepared Ni-La/α-Al2O3 catalysts by incipient wet impregnation and discovered that the addition of La may lead to significant changes in the surface of the nickel oxide sites. The replacement of Ni with La led to smaller and well-dispersed NiO particle sizes with strong metal-support interactions (SMSI). Zhang et al. [29] investigated the steam reforming of guaiacol, a model compound for volatiles in the biomass gasification process, over Ni/SiO2 modified with Na, Mg, or La. The results show that the addition of La increased the alkalinity to some extent, promoted the dispersion of Ni, and improved the catalytic activity and coking resistance. Based on the monofunctional and bifunctional catalytic mechanisms of cobalt-based catalysts, the adsorption and activation of CO2 take place on the surface of the catalyst support, while the cleavage of CH4 occurs on the active sites of Co [30]. The presence of acid sites can promote the decomposition of methane (CH4) into carbon and hydrogen, leading to coke deposition on the catalyst surface [30,31]. This coke formation can block active sites and reduce the efficiency of the catalyst in processes such as methane reforming or conversion. The acidity of the surface can play a significant role in determining the activation energy required for these reactions, with higher surface acidity generally lowering the activation energy for methane decomposition [32]. As a result, controlling the acidity of the catalyst surface is crucial in optimizing catalytic reactions involving methane. Recent research has centered on integrating alkali earth metals or alkaline metals into catalysts to explore their impact on catalytic performance [30-33]. Calles et al. [34] observed that the use of alkaline earth metal promoters effectively reduced carbon deposition, leading to enhanced stability of glycerol steam reforming catalysts. Zhao et al. [35] found that doping CeO2 with alkali metals affects its lattice alteration and activates lattice oxygen, resulting in increased activity and selectivity of the catalyst. Song and Ozkan [36]discovered that a Ca-doped Co/CeO2 catalyst increased the content of oxygen vacancies and thus improved oxygen mobility in ethanol steam reforming. Furthermore, the addition of alkali promoters to CoO has been shown to promote CO2 adsorption on the catalyst surface, enhancing catalyst activity [37]. This phenomenon arises from the increased alkalinity of the catalyst, which leads to a rise in the concentration of surface-activated O*, subsequently reducing its reaction with neighboring C* to form carbon deposits. Nevertheless, these studies focused on the addition of alkali earth metals as promoters in the catalytic system, without considering the individual characteristics of each support material. Furthermore, these studies overlooked the enhancement of surface texture properties and the modification of the physical and chemical environment of the catalyst support. Catalyst carriers play an important role in providing texture and physicochemical properties. Among the various types of carriers, the use of Al2O3 as a carrier for DRM catalysts is the most advantageous [38]. This is because Al2O3 exhibits excellent mechanical strength and thermal stability, surpassing other materials such as SiO2 and TiO2. Additionally, Al2O3 is inexpensive and readily available, making it an excellent choice for preparing cost-effective, high-performance DRM catalysts. Currently, only two crystalline forms of Al2O3, namely γ-Al2O3 and α-Al2O3, are commonly employed as catalyst carriers. The α-Al2O3 phase is highly stable, thereby enhancing the catalyst's thermal stability. On the other hand, γ-Al2O3, which is more volatile, possesses a higher specific surface area. This characteristic facilitates optimal dispersion of the active metal, while minimizing deactivation caused by sintering of the active phase [39,40]. To better prepare highly active and stable catalysts, this study constructed a composite support mAl2O3 (m=Ca, Mg, and Ba), modified with different alkali earth metals using impregnation, and subsequently employed this composite support to prepare CoLa catalysts for the dry reforming of methane. The impacts of introducing different alkali earth metals on the support and the catalyst surface structure were investigated. The effects of the various composite support on the catalyst surface chemistry, electronic effects, and activation capacity were probed using XPS, H2-TPD and CO2-TPD characterization. The influence of the composite support on the catalyst's performance was further examined using kinetics. 2 Experiment 2.1 Material Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)3·6H2O), calcium nitrate tetrahydrate (Ca(NO3)2·4H2O), lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O) and barium nitrate (Ba(NO3)2) were obtained from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. All analytical grade chemicals are applied directly as-received without any purification. The industrial grade alumina was used as a support. 2.2 Catalyst and support preparation The industrial alumina used in this study was pre-calcined at 550 °C for 2 h in a muffle furnace. The preparation method for the composite support is as follows: Firstly, quantitative alkali earth metal nitrate was dissolved in 20 mL of distilled water. Then, the treated alumina was added to the above solution and stirred continuously for 6 h at room temperature. After that, the mixture was dried at 110 °C for 12 h, and the obtained solid powder was calcined at 600 °C in an air atmosphere for 4 h to produce various alkali earth metal-modified m-Al2O3 (m=Ca, Mg, Ba) composite support. To prepare the catalysts, initially, a specific quantity of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and La(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in 20 mL of distilled water. Subsequently, a certain amount of m-Al2O3 (m=Ca, Mg, Ba) composite support was added to the mixed solution. The mixture was sonicated for 1 h at room temperature, stirred for 5 h, and then dried at 110 °C for 12 h. The resulting solid was then calcined at 550 °C for 4 h in an air atmosphere. The calcined catalyst is denoted as CoLa/m-Al2O3 (m=Ca, Mg, Ba). The loading of Co is 10% and the loading of La is 5 %. For comparison, CoLa/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using the same method but with industrial alumina support without alkali earth metal doping. Detailed characterization of the catalysts can be found in the Supporting Information (SI). 2.3 Catalytic performance test Catalyst activity and stability were assessed in a fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure, with temperatures ranging from 650 °C to 750 °C. A mixture of 0.12 gs of catalyst and quartz sand was loaded into a quartz tube with an inner diameter of 10 mm and a length of 50 cm. A thermocouple was inserted into the quartz tube to oversee temperature fluctuations throughout the reaction procedure. The gas chromatography system employed in the course of the reaction was GC-950, featuring a TDX-01 column and a TCD-H2/Ar detector. Initially, the temperature was ramped from ambient to 750 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under an N2 atmosphere. The catalysts were then subjected to reduction in an H2 atmosphere, followed by purging the remaining H2 with N2 for 30 min. The flow rate of the feed gas was controlled by a mass flow meter and the outlet gas flow rate was monitored by a soap film flow meter. Feed gasses containing CH4 and CO2 in a 1:1 ratio was introduced into the reactor at a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 60,000 mL·h − 1·gcat−1. Catalyst activity and stability were evaluated at temperatures of 650, 700 and 750 °C. Additionally, to further assess the catalyst's stability, DRM experiment was conducted at a temperature of 750 °C for 10 h. The XCH4 (CH4 conversion), XCO2 (CO2 conversion), and RH2/CO (molar ratio of H2 to CO), can be calculated using following Eqs. (5)-(7). (5) X C H 4 = F C H 4 , i n − F C H 4 , o u t F C H 4 , i n × 100 % (6) X C O 2 = F C O 2 , i n − F C O 2 , o u t F C O 2 , i n × 100 % (7) H 2 C O = F H 2 , o u t F C O , o u t Where F i n and F o u t represent the in and out volume flow rates of gas (mL/min). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural characteristics Fig. 1 (a) presents the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for different CoLa/m-Al2O3 catalysts. These isotherms exhibit type IV isotherms at higher relative pressures (P/P0 ≥ 0.5) and display H4-type hysteresis loops [41,42]. In accordance with the classification criteria prescribed by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), these characteristics signify that the catalysts possess mesoporous structures characterized by diverse sizes and irregular shapes [43]. Fig. 1(b) illustrates that the alkali earth metal-modified composite support catalyst has larger pore sizes and a wider pore distribution. This observation implies that the incorporation of alkali earth metals in the support material remarkably enhances the pore structure properties of the catalyst. Consequently, this facilitates the adsorption and desorption processes of gas molecules during the DRM reaction. The results of the weaving properties of different CoLa/m-Al2O3 catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . It can be observed from the table that the specific surface area of the different support catalysts follows the descending order: CoLa/Al2O3 > CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 > CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 > CoLa/Ca-Al2O3. Similarly, the pore volume decreases in the following order: CoLa/Al2O3 = CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 > CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 > CoLa/Mg-Al2O3. In the CoLa/Al2O3 and CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 catalysts, notwithstanding their high specific surface area, the crystalline size is relatively substantial. This points to an uneven distribution of active metals on the carrier surface, with a significant proportion of grains infiltrating the pores, resulting in a diminution of pore size [44]. In the scenario of composite carriers modified by alkaline earth metals, catalysts altered by Mg and Ca showcase diminished crystalline sizes, implying that the active metals can be aptly dispersed on the carrier surface, and their enlarged pore size is attributable to the robust interaction between the metal and the carrier [45-47]. This robust metal-carrier interaction also elucidates the uniform dispersion of active metals on the carrier surface in CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 and CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts. Additionally, the pore size of the alkali earth metal-modified support catalyst was significantly increased. This may be attributed to the stronger interaction between the composite support and the active Co species, resulting in an enlarged pore size. This facilitates the diffusion of reactant molecules as well as their conversion. Among them, the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts exhibit a larger pore size and a smaller specific surface area pore volume. This suggests that the catalyst has a better dispersion of active metals on the surface and enhanced mass transfer capability, ultimately leading to enhanced catalytic performance. 3.2 Crystal structure analysis The XRD patterns presented in Fig. 2 show the diffraction peaks of the catalysts after calcination. It is evident that γ-Al2O3 peaks are observed at 46.03° and 66.76° for all samples (JCPDS 04–0858) [48]. Notably, no alkali earth metal oxide phase is detected in the crystalline structure of the catalysts prepared with alkali earth metal-modified alumina. This suggests that the alkali earth metal is uniformly dispersed on the surface of the support, creating a composite metal support. After calcination, strong diffraction peaks at 31.27°, 36.85°, and 44.81° are exhibited by all catalysts. These characteristic peaks can be attributed to the spinel phase, which corresponds to either the Co3O4 phase (JCPDS 42-1467) [49] or the CoAl2O4 phase (JCPDS 82-2248). Since both phases are spinels and their diffraction peaks occur at the same position, it is difficult to differentiate between them. Previous studies have shown that the formation of CoAl2O4 typically occurs at calcination temperatures above 600 °C. However, in this study, the samples were calcined at 550 °C, making the formation of the CoAl2O4 phase unlikely. Therefore, it can be concluded that the Co species on the catalysts' surface primarily exist in the Co3O4 phase. Additionally, the diffraction peak of the Co species phase at 36.85° is sharper, and the peak width is reduced for the catalyst prepared using the alkali earth metal-modified support. This indicates that the composite supports formed after modification with alkali earth metals exhibit strong metal-support interactions. These interactions enhance the crystallinity and reduce the crystalline size of the Co species, which can have a positive catalytic effect on the catalyst's anti-carbon performance and stability. The average crystalline sizes of Co3O4 at 36.85° were determined for all catalysts using Scherer's formula, and the results are summarized in Table 1. According to the Table 1, the crystalline size of Co3O4 in the CoLa/Al2O3 catalyst is approximately 11.5 nm. In contrast, the crystalline size of the CoLa/m-Al2O3 catalyst was found to be less than 11 nm. This suggests that the composite support modified with alkali earth metal can significantly reduce the crystalline size of the Co species. This reduction in crystalline size can be attributed to the improved metal-support interaction of the composite support. The enhanced interaction promotes the dispersion of active metals on the catalyst surface and decreases the crystalline size of the active Co species [50-52]. As can be seen from Table 1, the peak width values of XRD decrease in the order of CoLa/Ca-Al2O3>CoLa/Mg-Al2O3>CoLa/Ba-Al2O3. The decrease in bulk crystalline size leads to an increase in lattice distortions and grain boundaries within the crystal, and these factors lead to an increase in the number of X-rays scattered within the crystal, which results in broadening of the diffraction peaks. Consistent with our previous conclusions that magnesium and calcium modified composite carriers can form smaller crystalline sizes [53,54]. Consequently, this facilitates the performance of the DRM reaction conducted by the catalyst. 3.3 Analysis of the reduction performance of catalysts The reduction performance of the CoLa/Al2O3 and CoLa/m-Al2O3 catalysts, as well as the interaction between the active metal and the support, were further investigated using the H2-TPR characterization. The results are displayed in Fig. 3 . Similar trends were observed for all catalysts. The H2-TPR analysis revealed three main reduction peaks, corresponding to the reduction of different Co species. The reduction peak in the low-temperature region (300–450 °C) corresponds to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO (Eq. (8)) [13]. The second reduction peak, occurring between 450 and 600 °C, is attributed to the reduction of the intermediate phase CoO to metallic Co (Eq. (9)). The reduction peaks in the higher temperature region (>600 °C) are associated with the reduction of CoOx species present on the surface and subsurface layers of the catalyst, which exhibit stronger interactions with the support [55]. Furthermore, the CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a significant reduction peak at higher temperatures (> 800 °C). This peak can be attributed to the reduction of spinel CoAl2O4 to Co (Eq. (10)) [56]. This indicates that only a very small fraction of the cobalt species in the CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalyst exists in the form of CoAl2O4 and is reduced under high-temperature conditions. So, the Co species present in this series of Co-based catalysts primarily consist of Co3O4, with only minimal amounts of CoAl2O4 species. (8) Co3O4 + H2→3CoO + H2O (9) CoO + H2→ Co + H2O (10) CoAl2O4 + H2 → Co + Al2O3 + H2O Compared to the CoLa/Al2O3 catalyst, the reduction peaks of the catalysts modified with Mg and Ca were significantly shifted to the high temperature direction. The intensity and width of the reduction peaks were also greatly increased. On one hand, these observations indicate a significant improvement in the metal-support interactions of both types of catalysts. On the other hand, it suggests that the catalyst produces a considerable amount of active species Co2+ during the reduction process, thereby contributing to its catalytic performance in the DRM reaction. Notably, the reduction peak areas of CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalysts at 450–800 °C were considerably lower than those of CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts. Additionally, the CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a reduction peak of CoAl2O4 in the high-temperature. This leads to the generation of a smaller number of active sites through reduction compared to CoLa/Mg-Al2O3, which affects the catalytic performance of the CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalyst. However, the reduction peaks of the Ba-modified catalysts shifted towards lower temperatures, and the intensity and width of the peaks slightly decreased. This indicates that the catalyst has a weak metal-support interaction and produces fewer active sites Co2+ after reduction, which is unfavorable for the DRM reaction. Furthermore, Table 2 illustrates that the alkali earth metal-modified supports, specifically Mg and Ca, significantly augment the reduction of Co species, thereby facilitating the creation of an increased number of active sites during the adsorption and activation of CH4. This aspect assumes a pivotal role in enhancing the performance of the catalyst. In contrast, it was observed that the catalyst modified with Ba demonstrated the most limited reduction. This observation could potentially account for its subpar activity and stability. 3.4 Electronic environment of catalyst surface elements In order to investigate the electronic environment of Co, La, and O elements on the surface of the calcined Co-based catalysts, XPS characterization of each sample was performed, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . The Co 2p spectra of all catalysts were split into Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 due to the spin-orbit splitting of the Co 2p spectra. The peaks at around 780.1 eV and 795.3 eV in Fig. 4(a) are attributed to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Co3+ [56,57]. The peaks near 781.7 eV and 797.5 eV are attributed to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Co2+, respectively. The binding energy of all catalysts was slightly higher than that of the monometallic Co3O4 phase. This is due to the strong interaction between Co3O4 and Al2O3. However, satellite peaks occur at 787.6 and 803.4 eV [58], indicating the presence of Co3O4 species on the catalyst surface. Based on the results of the Co 2p split peak fitting, it is evident that the peaks corresponding to Co2+ species in the catalysts prepared from alkali earth metal-modified composite supports are shifted towards lower binding energy compared to the CoLa/Al2O3 catalysts. This shift indicates an increase in electron cloud density around the periphery of the Co element, making it easier to acquire electrons from the surroundings. Consequently, there is a higher abundance of active site Co2+ species, which facilitates the dissociation of CH4 [21-23]. Hence, this positively contributes to the catalytic performance of the DRM reaction. Furthermore, to demonstrate the effect of introducing alkali earth metals on the electronic environment of Co species, the Co2+/Co3+ area ratio was determined based on the split-peak fitting, and the results are presented in Table 2. In comparison with the CoLa/Al2O3 catalyst, both the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 and CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited an increased Co2+/Co3+ ratio on their surfaces to varying degrees. This suggests that the incorporation of alkali earth metals effectively enhances the interaction between the metal and support. It further promotes electron transfer between active metals, leading to enhanced generation of active site Co2+ species and facilitating the efficient dissociation of CH4 [22,23]. However, the Co2+/Co3+ ratio of the CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 catalysts was relatively low. This suggests that the catalyst has fewer active sites, which is not favorable for the DRM reaction. This observation is consistent with the CH4 conversion profile obtained during the catalyst activity evaluation. Fig. 4(b) presents the La 3d XPS spectra, all catalyst exhibits four energy band peaks. These peaks correspond to La 3d5/2 (832.2–842.7 eV) and La 3d3/2 (849.0–860.1 eV). This indicates the presence of La species on the catalyst surface, primarily in the form of La2O3. Furthermore, compared to the CoLa/Al2O3 catalyst, the La 3d energy band peak of the CoLa/m-Al2O3 catalyst is shifted towards a higher binding energy. This shift suggests a decrease in the electron cloud density around the periphery of the La element, resulting in electron loss and transfer to the surface of the Co element. As a result, more active sites are formed. This finding confirms that the alkali earth metal composite support can enhance electron transfer on the surface of the active metal. Consequently, more active sites are generated, leading to an accelerated catalytic reaction. The O 1 s XPS spectra of all catalysts can be split into two peaks corresponding to two different types of oxygen species, as shown in Fig. 4(c). The peak at approximately 530.9 eV corresponds to lattice oxygen (OL), while the peak at around 532.0 eV is associated with surface adsorbed oxygen or oxygen in surface hydroxyl groups (OA) [59,60]. The concentration of oxygen vacancies in each catalyst was determined using the oxygen vacancy calculation formula (OV=OA/(OA+OL) × 100%), and the results are presented in Table 2. As observed from the table, the oxygen vacancy content follows the order: CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 > CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 > CoLa/Al2O3 > CoLa/Ba-Al2O3. This indicates that the introduction of Mg and Ca enhances the oxygen transfer ability of the metal oxides in the catalyst, resulting in an increased concentration of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. Consequently, this facilitates the gasification of carbon accumulation during the DRM reaction, thereby improving the catalytic performance of the Co-based catalyst and its resistance to carbon accumulation. Conversely, the oxygen vacancy concentration on the surface of the Ba-modified composite support catalyst is relatively low (49.17%). This implies that the presence of Ba may have an inhibitory effect on the electron transfer on the catalyst surface, impeding the generation of oxygen vacancies. 3.5 Effects of different promoters on catalytic performance Fig. 5 depicts the activity test results of four catalysts. The figure demonstrates that the conversion of CH4 and CO2 significantly increases as the temperature rises within the range of 650–750 °C. This can be attributed to the fact that the DRM reaction is an endothermic reaction, and higher temperatures within this range favor both the kinetics and thermodynamics of the reaction. Among the catalysts, CoLa/Al2O3 exhibited a 32.07% improvement in CH4 conversion and a 29.89% improvement in CO2 conversion. For CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts, the respective improvements were 28.06 % for CH4 conversion and 25.45 % for CO2 conversion. Similarly, CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalysts showed improvements of 29.39 % for CH4 conversion and 26.56 % for CO2 conversion. CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 catalysts exhibited the highest improvements, with a 32.68 % increase in CH4 conversion and a 35.63 % increase in CO2 conversion. Additionally, it was observed that under the same reaction temperature conditions, the conversion of CO2 was higher than that of CH4, resulting in an H2/CO ratio of less than 1 [61]. This indicates the possibility of a reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS). In each temperature range, CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 displayed the highest catalytic activity among all the tested catalysts, followed by CoLa/Ca-Al2O3. The lower catalytic activity of CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 suggests that Ba plays a significant inhibitory role in the overall catalytic activity. From these observations, we can infer that the support structure plays a crucial role in determining the catalyst's activity level. In conclusion, the results indicate that modifying the support surface with Mg and Ca leads to improved catalytic activity, while the inclusion of Ba has a negative impact on the overall performance. The support structure is an important factor in determining the activity level of the catalyst. The stability of the catalysts was tested, as shown in Fig. 6 . For the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts, after 10 h of reaction, the CH4 and CO2 conversions decreased from 92.3 % and 97.5 % to 89.8 % and 96.0 %, respectively. This indicates that the catalytic performance of this catalyst remained relatively stable with a slight decrease, demonstrating good stability. The CoLa/Al2O3 catalyst showed a significant decrease in catalytic performance after 10 h of reaction. The CH4 and CO2 conversions decreased from 85.7 % and 93.4 % to 74.2 % and 85.9 %, respectively. It is important to note that among the alkali earth metal-modified catalysts studied, the presence of Ba had a noticeable inhibitory effect on the DRM reaction. After 10 h of reaction, the catalyst containing Ba exhibited poor conversion and stability, with only 66.7 % conversion for CH4 and 81.8 % conversion for CO2. This decline may be attributed to carbon buildup or metal sintering. In this study, alkali earth metals other than Ba demonstrated a facilitative effect on the DRM reaction. This could be due to the strong basicity of elements such as Mg and Ca, which enhance the number of basic sites on the catalyst surface and cover the acidic sites on the alumina support. This is beneficial for improving the adsorption and dissociation of CO2 and effectively inhibiting carbon formation during the DRM reaction. Additionally, the introduction of alkali earth metals improves the interaction between the metal active species and the support. It reduces the particle size of the Co species, which facilitates the activation of CH4 by the catalyst. Overall, these results indicate that the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited better stability and maintained compared to the other catalysts. The presence of Ba had an inhibitory effect on the catalytic activity, while the inclusion of alkali earth metals such as Mg and Ca enhanced the catalytic performance by improving the adsorption capabilities and metal-support interactions. 3.6 Kinetic test The adsorption and activation of methane on the catalyst surface occurs through the binding of H to the active sites, followed by the formation of activated hydrogen (H*) and CH*x species. Consequently, the process bears resemblance to the adsorption and activation of molecular hydrogen. Leveraging this analogy, we employed H2-TPD analysis to elucidate both the quantity and potency of the catalyst's active sites [62]. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), it revealed that all catalysts have two desorption peaks. The first peak corresponds to hydrogen desorbed from the surface of the active metal Co, indicating a weak H2 adsorption site. Conversely, the second peak represents subsurface desorbed hydrogen or spilled hydrogen, which indicates a more strongly bound adsorption site on the catalyst surface [63]. According to literature [62], the peak associated with the catalytic site of the active metal is the first peak. In the case of the CoLa/m-Al2O3 catalysts, the weak H2 adsorption sites were observed to be significantly shifted towards lower temperatures. Additionally, both the peak intensity and peak area were considerably enhanced. These observations suggest that the CoLa/m-Al2O3 catalysts possess a higher number of active metal Co sites on their surfaces. Among the CoLa/m-Al2O3 catalysts, the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the largest desorption peak area, while the CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalyst had the second largest area. This can be attributed to the strong interaction between the composite support m-Al2O3 and the Co species and La oxides, facilitating electron transfer between them. As a result, a larger number of Co active sites are exposed on the surface of these catalysts. The strong interaction between the composite support m-Al2O3 and Co species, as well as La oxides, plays a crucial role in facilitating electron transfer between them. This interaction leads to the exposure of more Co active sites on the catalyst surface, resulting in a higher H2 desorption peak area for the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 and CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalysts. In contrast, the CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits the smallest H2 desorption peak area compared to the CoLa/Al2O3 catalyst. This suggests that the CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 catalyst has fewer H2 adsorption sites on its surface. Additionally, the amount of hydrogen desorbed through H2-TPD analysis provides insights into the active metal particle size, dispersion, and metal-specific surface area. Table 3 demonstrates that the H2 desorption of the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 and CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalysts significantly increases compared to the CoLa/Al2O3 catalyst. As a result, the catalyst surface possesses a higher density of active metal sites, which is conducive to the adsorption and activation of CH4 [62]. To investigate the adsorption and activation capacity of the catalyst sample for CO2, CO2-TPD characterization were conducted. Basic sites are commonly categorized into three types based on the desorption peaks observed during CO2 characterization experiments. (i) Weakly basic sites are found in the low-temperature region (below 300 °C) and are associated with the interaction between CO2 molecules and Brønsted hydroxyl groups. This allows the formation of bicarbonates on the weakly basic group OH. (ii) Medium alkaline sites appear in the 300–600 °C range and are linked to the presence of bidentate carbonate species. (iii) Strongly basic sites are observed above 600 °C, corresponding to the desorption of monodentate carbonates [64]. As evident from the curves in the Fig. 7(b), the intensity and width of the CoLa/Al2O3 catalyst's curves in the low and intermediate temperature regions are not significant. This suggests a limited presence of weakly basic and moderately basic sites for this specific catalyst. This indicates a limited number of weakly basic and moderately basic sites on this catalyst. Based on the curves shown in the Fig. 7(b), it is evident that the CoLa/Al2O3 catalysts display relatively low intensity and width of curves in the low and medium temperature regions. This suggests a limited presence of weakly basic and moderately basic sites on this catalyst. In contrast, the peak intensities and widths of the Ca and Mg-modified catalysts are significantly increased, indicating that these two alkali earth metals enhance the abundance of weakly basic and moderately basic sites on the catalyst surface. Consequently, this promotes the adsorption and activation of CO2 during the DRM reaction. Additionally, it is important to note that the Mg-modified catalysts display a wider range of peak widths for desorption peaks in the medium temperature region. This suggests the existence of various moderately basic sites on the catalyst surface, which is favorable for CO2 activation. Conversely, the Ba metal-modified catalysts exhibit strong desorption peaks solely in the low-temperature region, with significantly fewer peaks in the medium-temperature region when compared to the CoLa/Al2O3 catalysts. This indicates that the addition of Ba effectively enhances the presence of weakly basic sites on the catalyst. However, the catalytic performance of the Ba-modified catalysts seems to be somewhat inferior to that of CoLa/Al2O3, which aligns with the CO2 conversion results depicted in Fig. 6. In summary, the catalysts modified with Mg and Ca elements demonstrate excellent CO2 activation ability due to an enrichment of weakly basic and moderately basic sites. Nevertheless, the Ba-modified catalysts, despite their effectiveness in enhancing weakly basic sites, exhibit slightly poorer catalytic performance compared to CoLa/Al2O3. To further investigate the effect of catalysts with different alkali earth metal-modified supports on the DRM reaction, kinetic studies were conducted over four catalysts. The kinetic tests were carried out at low temperature and high gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) conditions (470–500 °C, GHSV = 144,000 mL∙h − 1·gcat −1). The apparent activation energies of CH4 and CO2 were calculated using the Arrhenius formula to assess each catalyst's potential for reactant activation, as presented in Fig. 7(c) and Fig. 7(d). The apparent activation energies of CH4 for the different alkali earth metal-modified support catalysts were as follows: CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 (67 kJ/mol) < CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 (72 kJ/mol) < CoLa/Al2O3 (83 kJ/mol) < CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 (88 kJ/mol). Similarly, the order of activation energy for CO2 aligns with that of CH4: CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 (61 kJ/mol) < CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 (69 kJ/mol) < CoLa/Al2O3 (75 kJ/mol) < CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 (80 kJ/mol). Based on the above results, it is evident that catalysts prepared with Mg and Ca modified composite supports exhibit lower EaCH4 and EaCO2 compared to the CoLa/Al2O3 catalysts. This indicates that these catalysts effectively reduce the apparent activation energy of the reactants. This reduction can be mainly attributed to the enhanced interaction between the metal and the support due to the alkali earth metal modification of the composite support. Moreover, the improved dispersion of metals on the catalyst surface facilitates the dissociation and activation of CH4 and CO2. It is important to note that the CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 catalyst has a higher apparent activation energy when compared to the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 and CoLa/Ca-Al2O3 catalysts. This suggests a weaker activation of CH4 and CO2 on the CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 catalyst, which is not favorable for the dissociation of reactants. This observation aligns with the activity and stability performance of each catalyst. The TOF values for all catalysts can be found in Table S1-S4. 3.7 Thermogravimetric analysis Figure 8(a) illustrates the qualitative and quantitative analyses conducted on the carbon accumulation of the spent CoLa/Al2O3 and CoLa/Mg-Al2O3, using TG and DTG. The spent CoLa/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a mass loss of 21.77%, while the spent CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalyst showed a lower mass loss of 7.15%. It indicates that the Mg-Al2O3 composite support has a certain inhibitory effect on the generation of carbon deposits. It is worth mentioning that weight loss occurring below 300 °C is associated with the removal of water and adsorbed impurities [24]. The mass loss observed between 420 - 620 °C can be attributed to the combustion of carbon deposits. In particular, the mass loss occurring at 550 °C is associated with the oxidation of amorphous carbon, while the mass loss above 600 °C may be attributed to the oxidation of filamentary or fibrous carbon [65]. From the Fig. 8 (b), it is evident that the carbon combustion center for the spent CoLa/Al2O3 is at 512.5 °C. However, for the spent CoLa/Mg-Al2O3, the carbon combustion center is at a lower temperature of 500.7 °C, indicating a significant shift towards lower temperatures. This suggests that the Mg-Al2O3 composite carrier can enhance the carbon accumulation resistance of Co-based catalysts, which is conducive to the generation of highly active and easily removable amorphous carbon on the surface of the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalysts during the reaction process [66-68]. Furthermore, in contrast to CoLa/Al2O3, CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 exhibited a reduced peak area in DTG and decreased mass loss in TG, suggesting superior anti-coking characteristics of CoLa/Mg-Al₂O₃. 3.8 Proposed reaction mechanism The phenomenon of carbon deposition is a significant factor that leads to catalyst deactivation. Understanding the process of carbon generation and elimination in reactions is crucial for achieving efficient utilization of catalysts. Based on the experimental and characterization results, a reaction mechanism for the CH4 CO2 reforming was proposed as shown in Fig. 9 . Firstly, CH4 dissociates at the Co active site, generating intermediates CHx* and H* species (CH4 → CHx* + (4-x)H*) [3,10]. Simultaneously, CO2 is activated through adsorption, producing CO* and O* species (CO2 → CO* + O*) [3,10]. The CHx* species and the adsorbed O* species then react to form CO and H2 [3]. The composite support alumina provides more alkaline sites than conventional industrial alumina. This enrichment facilitates the rapid diffusion of CO2, which in turn reacts with the generated carbon and reduces carbon deposition. Furthermore, the stronger interactions between Co and La metals result in the spontaneous transfer of electrons from the La surface to the Co species [24,25]. This process leads to the formation of more oxygen vacancies. The oxygen vacancies on the catalyst's surface act as adsorption and activation sites for CO2 and are more likely to dissociate, generating CO* and regenerating O* [25,69]. Another pathway for adsorption of CO2 is the rapid formation of La2O3 with CO2 to form La2O3CO3. This La-type oxycarbonate can further react with carbon from methane cracking to form CO [69-71]. In contrast, industrial alumina catalysts typically possess more acidic sites that are not favorable for the adsorption and dissociation of CO2. Consequently, this can lead to the formation of more filamentous carbon, where the active metal becomes encapsulated or detached from the support surface, eventually impairing the catalytic performance of the catalyst. These observations are consistent with the TG results. Therefore, the introduction of alkali earth metals can promote the adsorption of CO2 and effectively reduce the occurrence of carbon deposition, ultimately enhancing the catalytic performance and improving the DRM activity of the catalyst. 4 Conclusions This investigation observed that adjusting the fundamental sites on the support surface had an immense impact on the enrichment of active sites and the catalyst's activation ability. Catalysts fabricated with Mg and Ca modified supports exhibited a higher number of surface basic sites in comparison to CoLa/Al2O3 catalysts. This advancement encouraged the adsorption and activation of CO2. The incorporation of alkali earth metals additionally enhanced the interaction between the active metal and the composite support, which prohibited the formation of challenging-to-reduce phases like CoAl2O4 and advanced the reduction and dispersion of Co species. Thus, more active sites became accessible for the adsorption and activation of CH4, resulting in excellent catalytic activity. Moreover, apart from Ba metal, the introduction of alkali earth metals substantially amplified the oxygen-rich environment on the catalyst surface, resulting in the generation of more oxygen vacancies. This expedited the rate of carbon elimination and effectively improved the catalyst's resistance to carbon deposition and its catalytic stability. Kinetic studies illustrated that incorporating Mg and Ca effectively reduced the apparent activation energy of the reactants. Additionally, it was demonstrated that the introduction of alkali earth metals facilitated the cleavage of CH4 and the dissociation of CO2. Overall, this study provides novel insights into the design of catalysts having diverse surface properties of supports, broadening the possibilities for enhanced catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming of methane (DRM) is a novel technology that enables the direct utilization of greenhouse gases (CH4 and CO2) for the production of value-added products. In the DRM reaction, the acid-base characteristics of the catalyst support play a pivotal role in determining the performance of the catalyst. In this study, a series of Co-based catalysts with different alkali earth metal-modified Al2O3 composite supports, specifically m-Al2O3 (m=Ca, Mg, and Ba), were prepared using the impregnation method. Various characterization techniques were employed to investigate the impact of alkaline site modulation on the support surface with respect to anti-sintering and anti-coking properties. The results demonstrate that the m-Al2O3 composite support catalysts, prepared with Mg and Ca modulation, exhibit an abundance of basic sites and oxygen vacancies. This promotes the adsorption and activation of CO2, enhances the rate of carbon elimination, and effectively addresses carbon deposition and metal sintering issues. Notably, the CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalyst shows the highest performance under reaction conditions of 750 °C, with CH4 and CO2 conversions reaching 92.3 % and 97.5 %, respectively. On the other hand, the CoLa/Ba-Al2O3 catalysts display poor performance in dry reforming. Kinetic studies indicate that CoLa/Mg-Al2O3 catalyst significantly reduce the apparent activation energy required for CH4 and CO2 cracking. Furthermore, it is demonstrated that the introduction of alkali earth metals can promote the dissociation of CH4 and CO2.
coredata.dc:title: Surface basic site effect on CoLa/m-Al2O3 catalysts for dry reforming of methane
